Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: MultiScale Transport in Environmental and Physiological Systems (MultiSTEPS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transport processes such as fluid motion in biological systems at cellular, organismal and environmental levels are a key aspect of such challenges as targeted drug delivery, preventing cancer cell metastasis, and controlling pathogen spread through the biosphere. The discovery, analysis, and solution of critical issues in biological transport requires a new generation of truly interdisciplinary researchers who are educated in both engineering and biology, who merge these perspectives, and who can communicate effectively with fellow researchers, policy makers, and the public. The MultiSTEPS Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) program establishes a sustainable framework of interdisciplinary research and education that will prepare future leaders of academic and industrial research to collaborate on, analyze and solve emerging problems in transport that are at the intersection of the engineering and biological sciences.

Trainees advance through a systematic multi-step process of interdisciplinary coursework, peer interaction, community development and cross-disciplinary research experiences, including formal training in ethics and professional development. Training involves cross-disciplinary education through coursework and teaching experiences, community-building interactive seminars, interdisciplinary research rotations, international research opportunities, interaction with industry, and a unique internal collaborative grant competition among the trainees. Building upon the resources of Virginia Tech's Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity, the MultiSTEPS program will recruit and retain a diverse population of future innovators and equip them with the multidisciplinary intellectual tools and methods necessary to tackle complex and challenging problems in human health, and sustainable agricultural and environmental practices.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Multi-Scale Transport in Environmental and Physiological Systems (MultiSTEPS) IGERT program established a sustainable framework of interdisciplinary education and research at Virginia Tech that trained future leaders of industrial and academic research to think, collaborate, and contribute at the intersection of the biological and engineering sciences. This framework was based on a systematic, multi-step process of increasingly interdisciplinary coursework, trainee interaction, and research experience, and included ethics and professional development components. The MultiSTEPS program has equipped researchers to answer questions regarding multi-scale biological transport that could not be effectively addressed without a truly integrated education.  The MultiSTEPS program was active for 7 years as an NSF IGERT program and will continue operating at Virginia Tech as the BIOlogical TRANSport (BIOTRANS) program through support from the Virginia Tech Interdisciplinary Graduate Education Program (IGEP).  Twenty-two faculty participated in MultiSTEPS administration, teaching, and mentoring.  Twenty-six graduate students were supported financially as IGERT trainees with an average of 26.5 months of support per trainee.  Another 12 graduate students actively participated in the program as MultiSTEPS associates with supplemental financial support from Virginia Tech.  The NSF IGERT grant supported MultiSTEPS faculty and trainees in producing 106 peer-reviewed journal publications, two significant non-refereed publications (in Scientific American and Science), four book chapters, four patent applications, and 213 conference presentations.  Faculty and trainees also leveraged NSF IGERT funding to produce over 50 outreach activities including multiple summer research opportunities for public school science teachers and high school students, with many activities devoted to female students; development and delivery of high school teaching modules; expansion of entrepreneurship in higher education, including participation in the Virginia Governor's Entrepreneurship Council; contributions to two BBC documentaries; starting a Virginia Tech graduate student mentorship program for first-year under-represented and minority students; selection to produce one of three celldance videos in 2016 (http://www.ascb.org/celldance-selections/); and numerous features in the popular press, including articles by Popular Science, NPR, the New York Times and the L.A. Times. Research activities examined transport phenomena across a broad range of length and time scales in problems at the interface of engineering and biology.  Important research progress was made at the cellular scale, at the human scale, and at the atmospheric scale; one example of each is highlighted here. At the cellular scale, advances have been made in understanding the generation of abnormal chromosome number, how this abnormal chromosome number is related to cancerous tumor production, and the effect that external mechanical stresses have on this abnormal cell behavior.  At the human scale, significant progress has been made toward understanding local airborne disease transmission, particularly influenza.  Results indicate why the disease spikes in winter months in temperate regions and that shorter people may be exposed to higher concentrations of resuspended influenza virus. At the atmospheric scale, substantial progress was made in predicting the long-range spread of agricultural diseases by airborne plant pathogens, with applications extending broadly to the prediction of atmospheric transport.  Results indicate that specific atmospheric flow patterns play an important role in determining atmospheric concentrations of pathogens.
